title: Conditional-and-Interventional-Distribution
text: Let’s investigate model bnlearn (Scutari 2009).
code: # the following code is adapted from https://www.bnlearn.com/examples/custom-fitted/ library(bnlearn) R <- matrix(c(0.2, 0.8),              ncol = 2,              dimnames = list(NULL, c("TRUE", "FALSE")))  W <- matrix(data = c(.9, .2,                      .1, .8),              nrow = 2,             ncol = 2,             byrow = TRUE,             dimnames = list(c("TRUE", "FALSE"),                             c("TRUE", "FALSE")))  H <- matrix(data = c(.8, .05,                      .2, .95),              nrow = 2,             ncol = 2,             byrow = TRUE,             dimnames = list(c("TRUE", "FALSE"),                             c("TRUE", "FALSE")))  net = model2network("[R][W|R][H|R]") fit = custom.fit(net, dist = list(R = R,                                    W = W,                                    H = H)) print(fit) #>  #>   Bayesian network parameters #>  #>   Parameters of node H (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   #>        R #> H       TRUE FALSE #>   TRUE  0.80  0.05 #>   FALSE 0.20  0.95 #>  #>   Parameters of node R (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   #>  TRUE FALSE  #>   0.2   0.8  #>  #>   Parameters of node W (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   #>        R #> W       TRUE FALSE #>   TRUE   0.9   0.2 #>   FALSE  0.1   0.8

title: Conditional-and-Interventional-Distribution
text: Let’s first investigate conditional probability hydroplaning given windscreen wipers . can cpquery function (see ?bnlearn::cpquery): Now, let’s investigate conditional probability hydroplaning given windscreen wipers : can see knowing status windscreen wiper allows us also make better guess whether expect hydroplaning.
code: cpquery(fitted = fit,          event = (H == "TRUE"),          evidence = (W == "TRUE"),         n = 100000) #> [1] 0.4434798 cpquery(fitted = fit,          event = (H == "TRUE"),          evidence = (W == "FALSE"),         n = 100000) #> [1] 0.07277151

title: Conditional-and-Interventional-Distribution
text: interventional distribution look -called mutilated network (see ?bnlearn::mutilated). basic idea intervening windscreen wiper cut connection windscreen wiper parent nodes (rain). First, let’s look probability hydroplaning given turn windscreen wipers . following, note windscreen wipers W longer affected rain R: probability hydroplaning given turn windscreen wipers given : Now, let’s look probability hydroplaning given turn windscreen wipers : Note probability hydroplaning longer predicted windscreen wiper status. cut link parent node - rain R - intervening windscreen wiper.
code: mut <- mutilated(x = fit,                  evidence = list("W" = "TRUE")) print(mut) #>  #>   Bayesian network parameters #>  #>   Parameters of node H (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   #>        R #> H       TRUE FALSE #>   TRUE  0.80  0.05 #>   FALSE 0.20  0.95 #>  #>   Parameters of node R (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   #>  TRUE FALSE  #>   0.2   0.8  #>  #>   Parameters of node W (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   TRUE FALSE  #>     1     0 cpquery(fitted = mut,          event = (H == "TRUE"),          evidence = TRUE,         n = 100000) #> [1] 0.20054 mut <- mutilated(x = fit,                  evidence = list("W" = "FALSE")) print(mut) #>  #>   Bayesian network parameters #>  #>   Parameters of node H (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   #>        R #> H       TRUE FALSE #>   TRUE  0.80  0.05 #>   FALSE 0.20  0.95 #>  #>   Parameters of node R (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   #>  TRUE FALSE  #>   0.2   0.8  #>  #>   Parameters of node W (multinomial distribution) #>  #> Conditional probability table: #>   TRUE FALSE  #>     0     1  cpquery(fitted = mut,          event = (H == "TRUE"),          evidence = TRUE,         n = 100000) #> [1] 0.20083

title: Conditional-and-Interventional-Distribution
text: difference conditional interventional distribution SEM discussed detail Gische Voelkle (2022). apply ideas outlined SEM, use Political Democracy model fitted OpenMx (Neale et al. 2016). model given : First, translate model Bayesian network: Next, want investigate conditional distribution dem65 given y6 = 1. , use cpdist function generate samples. get interventional distribution, can use mutilated network: Note identical expected value dem65 (0; numerical imprecision due sampling). Let’s look another example. end, first check mean variance x1 network. Now, let’s check conditional mean variance x1 given dem60 = 3 Note knowledge dem60 provides us information indicator x1 ind60. intervening dem60, contrast, don’t change expectation x1:
code: library(mxsem) model <- '   # latent variable definitions      ind60 =~ x1 + x2 + x3      dem60 =~ y1 + a*y2 + b*y3 + c*y4      dem65 =~ y5 + a*y6 + b*y7 + c*y8    # regressions     dem60 ~ ind60     dem65 ~ ind60 + dem60    # residual correlations     y1 ~~ y5     y2 ~~ y4 + y6     y3 ~~ y7     y4 ~~ y8     y6 ~~ y8 '  mx_model <- mxsem(model,                   data = OpenMx::Bollen) |>   OpenMx::mxTryHard() network <- bnSEM::bnSEM(mx_model = mx_model) cond_dist <- bnlearn::cpdist(fitted = network$bayes_net,                               nodes = "dem65",                               evidence = list("y6" = 1),                               method = "lw") # Using likelihood weighting, we have to take the weights into account when # computing the expected value and the variance # mean (m <- sum(cond_dist$dem65 * attr(cond_dist, "weights")) / sum(attr(cond_dist, "weights"))) #> [1] -0.9471441 # variance sum(attr(cond_dist, "weights") * (cond_dist$dem65 - m)^2)/    sum(attr(cond_dist, "weights")) #> [1] 1.990131 mut <- mutilated(x = network$bayes_net,                   evidence = list("y6" = 1)) inter_dist <- cpdist(fitted = mut,                      nodes = "dem65",                      evidence = TRUE,                      method = "lw") # mean (m <- sum(inter_dist$dem65 * attr(inter_dist, "weights")) / sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights"))) #> [1] -0.01412657 # variance sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights") * (inter_dist$dem65 - m)^2)/    sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights")) #> [1] 4.554579 dist <- bnlearn::cpdist(fitted = network$bayes_net,                          nodes = "x1",                          evidence = TRUE,                          method = "lw") # mean (m <- sum(dist$x1 * attr(dist, "weights")) / sum(attr(dist, "weights"))) #> [1] 5.062848 # variance sum(attr(dist, "weights") * (dist$x1 - m)^2)/    sum(attr(dist, "weights")) #> [1] 0.5276746 cond_dist <- bnlearn::cpdist(fitted = network$bayes_net,                               nodes = "x1",                               evidence = list("dem60" = 3),                               method = "lw") # mean (m <- sum(cond_dist$x1 * attr(cond_dist, "weights")) / sum(attr(cond_dist, "weights"))) #> [1] 5.462163 # variance sum(attr(cond_dist, "weights") * (cond_dist$x1 - m)^2)/    sum(attr(cond_dist, "weights")) #> [1] 0.4428409 mut <- mutilated(x = network$bayes_net,                   evidence = list("dem60" = 10)) inter_dist <- cpdist(fitted = mut,                      nodes = "x1",                      evidence = TRUE,                      method = "lw") # mean (m <- sum(inter_dist$x1 * attr(inter_dist, "weights")) / sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights"))) #> [1] 5.052059 # variance sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights") * (inter_dist$x1 - m)^2)/    sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights")) #> [1] 0.529606

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jannik H. Orzek. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Christian Gische. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Orzek J, Gische C (2025). bnSEM: Translate SEM Bayesian Networks. R package version 0.1.1, https://jhorzek.github.io/bnSEM/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {bnSEM: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks},   author = {Jannik H. Orzek and Christian Gische},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.1},   url = {https://jhorzek.github.io/bnSEM/}, }

title: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks
text: Structural Equation Models (SEM) Bayesian Networks closely related. objective bnSEM (Bayesian Network SEM) easily transition SEM Bayesian Networks. end, bnSEM translates SEM fitted OpenMx (Neale et al., 2016) Bayesian Networks bnlearn (Scutari, 2009).

title: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks
text: can install development version bnSEM GitHub :

title: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks
text: first estimate SEM OpenMx. Next, translate model Bayesian Network: get impression network, can create plot:
code: library(mxsem) model <- '   # latent variable definitions      ind60 =~ x1 + x2 + x3      dem60 =~ y1 + a*y2 + b*y3 + c*y4      dem65 =~ y5 + a*y6 + b*y7 + c*y8    # regressions     dem60 ~ ind60     dem65 ~ ind60 + dem60    # residual correlations     y1 ~~ y5     y2 ~~ y4 + y6     y3 ~~ y7     y4 ~~ y8     y6 ~~ y8 '  mx_model <- mxsem(model,                   data = OpenMx::Bollen) |>   OpenMx::mxTryHard() library(bnSEM) network <- bnSEM::bnSEM(mx_model = mx_model) library(qgraph) qgraph::qgraph(network$dag)

title: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks
text: Bayesian Network, can now investigate conditional distribution variables model (see vignette("Inference-Example", package = "bnSEM") comparison rejection sampling)   Additionally, can investigate interventional distributions. fairly experimental really tested - take everything following large grain salt. bnlearn, interventional distribution can investigated using mutilated networks. example, let’s assume intervene latent dem60 variable setting value 2: can investigate distribution dependent variable dem65 higher original estimates mean variance dem65 dem60 effect dem65: Now, let’s also look expected value ind60: dem65 effect ind60, identical estimated mean covariance ind60 original model:
code: # Check conditional distribution # probability that dem65 in (1,2) given dem60 > 1: bnlearn::cpquery(fitted = network$bayes_net,                  event = (dem65 > 1 & dem65 < 2),                  evidence = (dem60 > 1)) #> [1] 0.3410203  # Get distribution under this assumption: dist <- bnlearn::cpdist(fitted = network$bayes_net,                         node = "dem65",                         evidence = (dem60 > 1)) hist(dist$dem65) # Now check dem60 < -1 dist <- bnlearn::cpdist(fitted = network$bayes_net,                         node = "dem65",                         evidence = (dem60 < -1)) hist(dist$dem65) mut <- mutilated(x = network$bayes_net,                   evidence = list("dem60" = 2)) inter_dist <- cpdist(fitted = mut,                      nodes = "dem65",                      evidence = TRUE,                      method = "lw") # mean (m <- sum(inter_dist$dem65 * attr(inter_dist, "weights")) / sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights"))) #> [1] 1.733022 # variance sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights") * (inter_dist$dem65 - m)^2)/    sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights")) #> [1] 0.3253716 mx_model$M$values[,"dem65"] #> dem65  #>     0 mx_model$S$values["dem65", "dem65"] #> [1] 0.1644651 inter_dist <- cpdist(fitted = mut,                      nodes = "ind60",                      evidence = TRUE,                      method = "lw") # mean (m <- sum(inter_dist$ind60 * attr(inter_dist, "weights")) / sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights"))) #> [1] 0.0002731072 # variance sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights") * (inter_dist$ind60 - m)^2)/    sum(attr(inter_dist, "weights")) #> [1] 0.4469307 mx_model$M$values[,"ind60"] #> ind60  #>     0 mx_model$S$values["ind60", "ind60"] #> [1] 0.4485991

title: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks
text: check Bayesian Network, can also simulate data network refit SEM check estimates align:

title: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks
text: transitioning SEM Bayesian Network, central challenge use covariances parameters SEM. translate covariances model can easily used Bayesian Networks, bnSEM replaces covariances direct effects unobserved phantom variables. approach explained detail, instance, Merkle & Rosseel (2015; see p. 8).

title: Translate SEM to Bayesian Networks
text: OpenMx: Neale, M. C., Hunter, M. D., Pritikin, J. N., Zahery, M., Brick, T. R., Kirkpatrick, R. M., … & Boker, S. M. (2016). OpenMx 2.0: Extended structural equation statistical modeling. Psychometrika, 81, 535-549. bnlearn; Scutari, M. (2009). Learning Bayesian networks bnlearn R package. arXiv preprint arXiv:0908.3817. Merkle, E. C., & Rosseel, Y. (2015). blavaan: Bayesian structural equation models via parameter expansion. arXiv preprint arXiv:1511.05604.

title: bnSEM — bnSEM
text: bnSEM (Bayesian network SEM) translates OpenMx models Bayesian networks fitted bnlearn. resulting network can used investigate conditional distributions SEM.

title: bnSEM — bnSEM

title: bnSEM — bnSEM
text: list bayes_net: fitted Bayesian network class bn.fit dag: underlying directed acyclical graph internal: Internal elements

title: bnSEM — bnSEM
text: Bayesian networks, dependencies variables must expressed directed "effects". covariance sense OpenMx. Instead, must replace covariances effects latent phantom variable. instance x1 <-> x2 replaced ph -> y1; ph -> y2; ph <-> ph. resulting model identical initial OpenMx model terms fit, residual variance estimates change. bnSEM currently supports three different approaches: First, using phantom_type = "refit-free-loadings", bnSEM add phantom variables covariances re-estimate SEM. "refit-free-loadings", loadings phantom observed variables (1) constraint equality covariance positive (2) constraint equal values, opposite signs covariances negative. variance constraint one. based discussion Prof. Marcel Paulssen bifactor modeling approach. Second, using phantom_type = "refit-free-single-loading", bnSEM also add phantom variables covariances re-estimate SEM. However, contrast "refit-free-loadings" one loadings estimated, one constraint. results exactly fit first approach based suggestion Dr. Christian Gische. advantage refitting approaches manifest latent variable original model still residual variance new model Bayesian Network. necessary cpdist work expected. main disadvantages (1) refitting may fail (2) constraints variance covariance parameters accounted . Third, using phantom_type = "cholesky", bnSEM replace full residual (co-)variance matrix Cholesky decomposition (S = DD^t). latent manifest variables (v) original model now given v = Du, u vector size v standard-normally distributed items. main advantage Cholesky decomposition approach require refitting model therefore also result non-convergence. main disadvantage variable original model now determined fully new variables u. , none original variables residual variances new model. can result unexpected behavior using cpdist model, distributions deterministic variables work. approach suggested Prof. Manuel C. Voelkle.

title: cov_to_phantom — cov_to_phantom
text: bnSEM currently supports two different approaches: First, using phantom_type = "refit", bnSEM add phantom variables covariances re-estimate SEM. advantage approach manifest latent variable original model still residual variance new model Bayesian Network. necessary cpdist work expected. main disadvantages (1) refitting may fail (2) constraints variance covariance parameters accounted . implementation improved Dr. Christian Gische. Second, using phantom_type = "cholesky", bnSEM replace full residual (co-)variance matrix Cholesky decomposition (S = DD^t). latent manifest variables (v) original model now given v = Du, u vector size v standard-normally distributed items. main advantage Cholesky decomposition approach require refitting model therefore also result non-convergence. main disadvantage variable original model now determined fully new variables u. , none original variables residual variances new model. can result unexpected behavior using cpdist model, distributions deterministic variables work. approach suggested Prof. Manuel C. Voelkle.

title: cov_to_phantom_cholesky — cov_to_phantom_cholesky
text: cov_to_phantom_cholesky uses Cholesky decomposition represent covariance matrix entire model. approach suggested Manuel C. Voelkle. See, example, p. 462 Klein, ., & Moosbrugger, H. (2000). Maximum likelihood estimation latent interaction effects LMS method. Psychometrika, 65(4), 457-474. main advantage using Cholesky decomposition refitting model required. result, many convergence issues avoided. main disadvantage Cholesky decomposition approach just "outsourcing" covariances new phantom variables, also variances. result, observed latent variables original model now fully determined new latent variables. results issues bnlearn, conditional distributions computed.

title: cov_to_phantom_refit_loadings — cov_to_phantom_refit_loadings
text: Bayesian networks, dependencies variables must expressed directed "effects". covariance sense OpenMx. Instead, must replace covariances effects latent phantom variable. instance x1 <-> x2 replaced ph -> y1; ph -> y2; ph <-> ph. resulting model identical initial OpenMx model terms fit, residual variance estimates change. current implementation, loadings phantom observed variables (1) constraint equality covariance positive (2) constraint equal values, opposite signs covariances negative. variance constraint one. based discussion Prof. Marcel Paulssen bifactor modeling approach.
